Dialogue.NPCText:
In a small clearing, a figure hunched over a fallen log traces intricate runes into bone. Around them, flutes, whistles, and animal talismans dangle from branches. Ori mutters to each in turn: “Patience, little owl. Courage, wolf tooth. You’ll sing soon enough…”

Sensing you, Ori’s eyes dart up—half wary, half wild.

“Do you hear them too? The bones whisper when the wind is right. But I need a listener with living ears. What brings you beneath the hollow tree?”

Option.text: I heard you craft magical flutes.
Who are you, really?
Are you talking to your... tools?
Need help with something?
Tell me more about yourself, Ori.
Just passing through.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori smiles, fingers tapping on a bone flute. “The right bone remembers the wind, the song of its spirit. My flutes call birds, beasts, or storms if you play true. I could carve you one, but first… the woods ask for a song I cannot play—yet.”

Option.text: What song do the woods want?
How do you learn these songs?
That sounds unsettling. I’ll be going.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori holds up a flute, whispering, “This one says names are wind on water—gone before you grasp them. But the tribe calls me Ori. I find music in what others throw away. Bones, bark, dreams, secrets… They all sing if you listen.”

Option.text: Do you always talk to things?
What are you working on now?
That’s enough riddles for me.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori grins, pressing a finger to his lips. “Bones forget less than people do. Each flute remembers a beast’s last song, each knife its old hunger. Wouldn’t you talk to them, if you could?”

Option.text: What do your tools want today?
You’re a strange one, Ori.
I’ve heard enough.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Some say the wind brings new tunes. Others, that the roots remember everything. But the oldest music comes from the heart of lost things. That is why I seek the singing stag’s bones—its song can wake the sleeping woods.”

Option.text: Tell me about this singing stag.
Roots remember? That’s poetic.
This is too strange for me.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori’s eyes crinkle. “Even stones hum, if you listen long enough. Roots, bones, rain—every silence is a song waiting for ears.”

Option.text: What silence are you listening for?
Thank you for sharing, Ori.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori leans close, voice low. “I have carved every beast but one—the singing stag. Its bones ring with spirit-music, but the stag wanders the haunted grove. I dare not go alone; the shadows there are thick with Minax’s spite. Will you seek its resting place with me?”

Option.text: Yes, I’ll help you find the singing stag’s bones.
What dangers lurk in the haunted grove?
What will you do with the stag’s bones?
I’m not sure I’m ready.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori’s face brightens, and he presses a rune-etched talisman into your palm. “Take this. The grove will not welcome you, but play its note and I may hear if you falter. Bring me the stag’s rib—whole, not shattered—and you will hear a song that calls even spirits from slumber.”

Option.text: I’ll return with the stag’s bone.
Anything else I should know?

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori’s gaze darkens. “Shadows twist in the grove, wearing the faces of old friends. Some spirits hunger for what was stolen from them. If Minax’s minions linger, trust not what you see or hear. Only the flute’s note can show truth from trick.”

Option.text: How do I use the talisman?
What reward awaits for this risk?
I must prepare first.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Hold the talisman tight. When fear grips you, breathe deep and play its note. I will come if I can, or perhaps the woods will take pity. But do not break the bone—music must be whole, or all is lost.”

Option.text: Thank you. I will be careful.
What if I fail?

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori’s voice softens, “If you break the bone, the song is lost. But every lost thing finds its way eventually. Return to me, and we’ll try again. The woods do not give up their secrets easily.”

Option.text: Understood. I’ll try again when I am ready.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Return with the stag’s rib, and I will carve a flute that can calm beasts or summon rain, depending on your heart’s tune. Some say it can even guide spirits—if you play it for the lost, perhaps they will find their way home.”

Option.text: That’s a worthy reward. I accept.
Thank you, Ori. I’ll return soon.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori nods, murmuring to a line of bone flutes, “The wind brings and takes as it will. If you wish to hear the bones sing, return when you’re ready.”

Option.text: Maybe I will.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori gently sets down a carved flute, brushing its bone like a parent might a child’s cheek. “Ah. A curious spirit. Few ask of Ori before asking for favors. But I’ll share—if your ears don’t close to strangeness.”

Option.text: I’ll listen. Tell me your story.
What makes you different from the others?
Where did you learn to carve spirits into bone?
That’s alright. I changed my mind.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori leans back against the hollow tree. “I was born during the Blackwind—when the stars fell silent and Minax’s screams echoed in the glades. My mother birthed me alone, save for the deer who circled her in quiet witness. She says they named me.”

Option.text: That’s beautiful… or terrifying.
You were named by deer?

Dialogue.NPCText: “Terrifying things are often beautiful—if you're brave enough to look long. I survived sickness, war, even a fire that claimed half the grove. My voice didn’t come until I carved my first flute. They say I was silent for seven years.”

Option.text: So your flutes gave you a voice?
What happened during the fire?

Dialogue.NPCText: “Yes. The first one was made from the leg bone of a rabbit who died in my arms. I carved it while grieving—and when I played it, I spoke aloud for the first time. Not words, but meaning. Sound that felt like home.”

Option.text: That’s... oddly moving.
You’re more spirit than man, aren’t you?

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori smiles sadly. “Perhaps. Or perhaps I simply listen when others don't. The bones remember what we forget. I honor them, and they whisper their secrets in return.”

Option.text: You mentioned a fire—what happened?
Let’s speak of something else.

Dialogue.NPCText: “It was the last time we saw the sun for three days. A shard-storm cracked the sky, and something dark fell into the glade. It brought with it a scream, like a dying songbird—but with teeth. I was the only survivor from my hut circle.”

Option.text: That sounds like Minax’s work.
I’m sorry you lost so much.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori nods slowly. “Yes. Some say she hunts the notes that can undo her. I believe the singing stag knows one such note. That is why I must find it—before her silence swallows the last songs of the world.”

Option.text: Then I understand your quest.
I’d like to ask something else.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori chuckles. “I sleep in trees. Speak to fire as though it were kin. And if I whisper to a feather or rock, it’s because they once whispered to me. The Verdant shamans call it madness. I call it memory.”

Option.text: You speak to spirits?
That sounds like wisdom, not madness.
Hmm. I’ll be going now.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Yes, though not with words. I carve what they remember into instruments. Every breath you play is a question. Every note—an answer from the dead.”

Option.text: Have you ever summoned a spirit that way?
Let’s talk about something else.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori’s eyes grow distant. “Once… I played the rib of a drowned druid. The storm answered. It struck a tree bare beside me—but I was not harmed. I think… the druid guided the lightning.”

Option.text: You are a lightning-touched madman, Ori.
That’s incredible.

Dialogue.NPCText: “Perhaps. Or perhaps the world is not as silent as most pretend. When you’ve carved as long as I have, you learn: the trees gossip more than any courtier.”

Option.text: Thank you for trusting me with your story.
Back to your flute—it mentioned a task?

Dialogue.NPCText: “An old druid named Ruun taught me. Said I was ‘too quiet not to be a carver.’ He passed on during the white frost, but I still dream of his voice. He always called me ‘his last knife.’”

Option.text: He must’ve been important to you.
Do you still speak to him?
Let’s change topics.

Dialogue.NPCText: Ori nods. “The deer bowed and stood still as stone. My mother said the spirit in their eyes was older than any man. She named me ‘Ori’ for the way they stared—like I already knew the ending.”

Option.text: That’s... oddly fitting.
Option.action: SendMessage:You feel a strange stillness settle over the glade.

Option.text: That’s creepy, not spiritual.
Option.action: SendMessage:Ori frowns, pulling slightly away from you.
